content.description:
Climb starts in the middle of the slab. Difficult climbing near the first few bolts, easier above. Located in the middle of the small slab at the North end of the main wall. 5 bolts w/ 2 bolt anchor Climb starts in the middle of the slab.
Difficult climbing near the first few bolts, easier above. Located in the middle of the small slab at the North end of the main wall. 5 bolts w/ 2 bolt anchor

Climb the fractured left arete of the shaded slab at the north end of the wall. Crux is near the bottom. Named after the large block wedged in the crack immediately to the left.

On the left edge of the slab at the North end of the wall.
5 Bolts w/ 2 bolt anchor

The most obvious crack line in the central part of the crag, veering left out of a grimmer vegetated line. Retrobolted in the early 2000s, the hangers were subsequently stripped leaving a line of hangerless studs next to the crack line. Begin up the crack on good incut holds to a blank section (can protect with wire nut cinched over hangerless bolt) where a step left on thin holds and a few face moves gain the upper crack system. Most obvious crack line in the central part of the cliff.

A trail runs around to climber's right and can be used for descent Gear to 3" plus hangerless bolt studs. Bolts at top possibly hangerless. Can use long slings to anchor off trees 10m back from cliff edge.

Climb up small ledges to the dish near the top of the wall.

Near the North side of the main wall.
5 bolts w/ 2 bolt anchor

This is the lefthand most route on the crag, beginning with an annoying wide and leafy crack that narrows down to a juggy seam above. There are a couple of 2000's era retrobolts beside the crack partway up.

At the left end of the crag, just right of a dirty gully.
A green Big Bro is useful for the wide opening moves. Above that, several bolts and small wires through #1 Camalot can be placed.

Climb up juggy holds on the right edge of the slab up and over a few small bulges to the top. This route shares an anchor with Baby Maple.

On the right edge of the shaded slab at the North end of the wall.
3 bolts w/ 2bolt anchor (shared w/ Baby Maple)

East facing shady crag in the forest on Sumas Mountain near Straiton. Mostly moderate climbing, and never busy. The closest crag to Abbotsford. Needs some TLC if it is ever to become popular.  
  
 Originally developed in the early 1990s, the crag fell into disuse before a second wave of development (sadly with some retrobolting of established trad lines) c. 2001.
